Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Situation2: They see a swimmer struggling near the middle of the pool and need to stay vigilant to respond quickly.
Story:
I sat on the high lifeguard chair, the sun beating down on my shoulders, scanning the pool for any signs of trouble. My phone buzzed in my pocket—a text from my stepdad, just checking in. He and Mom always said it was important to keep in touch, especially on weekends when I was busy. I knew they worried, wanted to feel included in my life, and I’d promised to text back whenever I could. 

But as I glanced at the message, I caught a glimpse of a swimmer in the middle of the pool, their strokes faltering, head bobbing awkwardly. My training screamed at me to keep my eyes on the water, to be ready to jump in at any second. I felt the pressure of both worlds closing in—my family expecting a quick reply, my job demanding unwavering attention. My heart pounded as I stared at my phone, torn between the need to reassure my parents and the responsibility to protect the swimmers. I gripped the phone tightly, caught in the moment, unsure which role to answer first.
